@adambom, that sounds like a good idea too. Would you be ok amending the PR for this?

I would be happy to review it since I wrote the original.
merge conflict! otherwise LGTM
Oh nice, I think it's our first non-abstract example! Can you please rebase, I think you may have branched off while landscape was broken...
You should set up landscape against your fork and rebase, you'll get some linting error to fix. This repo is now pretty strict about PEP8 and other coding standards, make the code feel more uniform.
Looks like you have a reference to something that is not deep-copyable in your DAG... I usually use PDB and go up the stack until I find which object causes the issue

Ok, I built the recipes for airflow and the dependencies that I couldn't find in an existing conda channel:

https://github.com/phumke/conda-recipes

And I uploaded the packages to conda:

https://anaconda.org/phumke

I haven't had a chance to test all of the packages out yet, so let me know if you run into any issues.  I know that gunicorn and setproctitle are fixing their windows support, so the win version of those probably don't work yet.

Also, there is a decent sized dependency tree for airflow that you'll have to download.  I have most of those listed in a text file, so if you want that list let me know and I can send that over.

Thanks for the comments and compliments.
Really loving the Airflow community! I will rebase, make those changes, and open a new pull request. Thank you once again max, you rock!

(JLowin: edited to add code blocks)

### main_dag.py

``` python
from datetime import datetime, timedelta
from airflow.models import DAG
from airflow.operators.subdag_operator import SubDagOperator
from subdag import sub_dag


PARENT_DAG_NAME = 'parent_dag'
CHILD_DAG_NAME = 'child_dag'
default_args = {
    'owner': 'shawn',
    'start_date': datetime(2016, 1, 1),
}

main_dag = DAG(dag_id=PARENT_DAG_NAME, default_args=default_args)

sub_dag = SubDagOperator(
  subdag=sub_dag(PARENT_DAG_NAME, CHILD_DAG_NAME, default_args),
  task_id=CHILD_DAG_NAME,
  dag=main_dag,
)
```

### subdag.py

``` python
from airflow.models import DAG
from airflow.operators.dummy_operator import DummyOperator



def sub_dag(parent_dag_name, child_dag_name, default_args):
  dag = DAG(
    '%s.%s' % (parent_dag_name, child_dag_name),
    default_args=default_args
  )

  dummy_operator = DummyOperator(
    task_id='dummy_task',
    dag=dag,
  )

  return dag
```

airflow test parent_dag parent_dag.child_dag 2016-01-01

@xiaoliangsc the first problem is that it looks like you are trying to execute the subdag (`parent_dg.child_dag`) rather than the subdag task (`child_dag`) -- I think what you're trying to do is `airflow test parent_dag child_dag 2016-01-01`, right?

However, that still creates an error. The reason is that airflow needs to be able to load all DAGs, including subdags, from the file in which they're defined. In your code, you define the subdag as an argument, which means it isn't available to be loaded.

If instead you do this, it will work:

### main_dag.py

``` python
from datetime import datetime, timedelta
from airflow.models import DAG
from airflow.operators.subdag_operator import SubDagOperator
from subdag import sub_dag


PARENT_DAG_NAME = 'parent_dag'
CHILD_DAG_NAME = 'child_dag'
default_args = {
    'owner': 'shawn',
    'start_date': datetime(2016, 1, 1),
}

main_dag = DAG(dag_id=PARENT_DAG_NAME, default_args=default_args)

# define sub dag outside the operator
subdag_object = sub_dag(PARENT_DAG_NAME, CHILD_DAG_NAME, default_args)

sub_dag = SubDagOperator(
  subdag=subdag_object,
  task_id=CHILD_DAG_NAME,
  dag=main_dag,
)

```

I will think about whether we can "look inside" `subdagoperators` so you can do it your original way as well.

if you create subdag_object in the main_day.py, isn't it scheduled separately by the scheduler? I thought the whole point of using a subdag is to schedule subdag only as part of the main dag? Maybe I'm missing some pieces here.

Originally Airflow ran only on schedules, and the primary key for a task instance was defined as dag_id, task_id and execution_date. When we added the notion of externally triggered DAGs (not on a schedule), we kept the PK as an artifact since changing that would require a significant refactor. 

We did introduce the notion of run_id though that also has to be unique. (I believe there's a unique constraint on dag_id, run_id)

Anyhow, changing that would require much more work than working around it. (What should the tree view look like for instance?) So I'd suggest running around it. 

Running on schedule brings a lot of clarity to batch processing (though it's not always ideal or even possible). I'd consider having a job that run say every hour and batch processes all the files that have accumulated.

Could be the threadpool in the `LocalExecutor` within the DagBag. We tend to use `SequentialExecutor` for subdag to avoid over subscribing worker. If a worker has 32 slots and each one uses a LocalExecutor you can end up with more threads than you signed up for...

Something that may help would be to override the `__deepcopy__` of BaseOperator and do some explicit logging on what fails there.

Hi @0xR 
What is your expectation here? 

Refer to https://pythonhosted.org/airflow/scheduler.html#scheduling-triggers

Specifically,
"Note that if you run a DAG on a schedule_interval of one day, the run stamped 2016-01-01 will be trigger soon after 2016-01-01T23:59. In other words, the job instance is started once the period it covers has ended."

An example cron schedule could be `0,15,30,45 * * * * *`, which means to run every 15 minutes.
So, 
- at `12:15:01`, the `12:00` run would start
- at `12:30:01`, the `12:15` run would start
- at `12:45:01`, the `12:30` run would start
- at `13:00:01`, the `12:45` run would start

Now, when you specified `0 0,5 * * *`, this worked as intended.

```
[2016-02-27 00:00:01,281] {local_executor.py:29} INFO - LocalWorker running airflow run my_dag start 2016-02-26T05:00:00 --local -sd DAGS_FOLDER/my_dag.py 
[2016-02-27 05:00:01,305] {local_executor.py:29} INFO - LocalWorker running airflow run my_dag start 2016-02-27T00:00:00 --local -sd DAGS_FOLDER/my_dag.py 
[2016-02-28 00:00:01,285] {local_executor.py:29} INFO - LocalWorker running airflow run my_dag start 2016-02-27T05:00:00 --local -sd DAGS_FOLDER/my_dag.py 
```

At `2016-02-27 00:00:01,281`, the period starting at `2016-02-26T05:00:00` was covered (or closed), meaning that `2016-02-26T05:00:00` could be scheduled.

Hope this makes sense. But, I'm closing this as NAB. If you have further questions, find me on [gitter](https://gitter.im/airbnb/airflow)

Right.. I looked at the code. I was sort of hinting that we could possibly change the web app to execute the deletes without using the ORM. I don't yet know how to override that in flask-admin.

The CLI backfill and the scheduler are in fact 2 separate processes and both `schedule` work. As a result, both can read the current queue size and result in oversubscription of the queue. There is a https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/wiki/Roadmap item for this under `Backfill offers a parallel code path to scheduling`

Ok I think I understand what is going on. However it makes templating the day before the execution day impossible. What I did to work around the issue is make 2 dags: 1 runs at 1am and 2 run at 5am. This way I know the execution date is the day before the actual run date. Knowing that I can use `{{ tomorrow_ds}}` as the current date in my template. 

I guess I am missing a template variable which has the date / time on which the dags scheduled to run. This dat will be different from the date of the data the dag run covers.

I have been able to test this a bit more. 

We have a situation where all `retries` for a task have been exhausted by the scheduler/worker and task status set to `failed`. Some tasks of same `dag_run` were successful. We thought that setting a task status to `up_for_retry` in the UI would give the failed task another retry but it doesn't. The parent `dag_run` have status `failed` which might be the reason the task is not retried?

Is this behavior correct and if so, what is our alternatives for repairing the failed task? Ideally, we would like both task and dag_run status to be `success` afterwards.

Wanted to comment on the extreme value of examples like this. I've got no skin in the game for this PR, but this would def. help some newcomers to Hive+Airflow in my team understand incremental tasks better. Thanks guys!

It seems that the scheduler doesnt currently expose any ports (only webserver does). So with our current model, we can only identify down to the unique hosts that are running. We could either use the unique baseJobs id to identify each scheduler (but user wont be able to know which id maps to which port/instance); or we could add port # or a user-defined name to pass in as CLI argument.

Thanks for reporting. Can you quickly confirm for me that you are running in UTC everywhere?
